course.subject: MATH
course.name: Multivariable Calculus
course.description: Sequences, series, gradients, chain rule. Extrema, Lagrange multipliers, line integrals, multiple integrals. Green's theorem, Stoke's theorem, divergence theorem, change of variables.
course.prerequisites: A passing grade in AL Pure Mathematics / AL Applied Mathematics; OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024

reviews.author: Rigbones
reviews.title: Friendly professor
reviews.comment_content:
Same as other reviews,
not that much more content compared to MATH 2011 actually
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ok, the professor is definitely friendly and very willing to help students, but honestly his teaching can be hard to understand at times.  

Luckily, he is open to constructive criticism so you can always make suggestions and he will try to adopt him.

One of the most important things of teaching math is demonstrating examples, and Prof Zhang Hai demonstrates quite a lot of examples in class, good!
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
95 or above, A+
85 or above, A-
65 or above, B-
50 or above, C-
40 or above, Pass.

The prof adjusted the grading scheme for B and C range.  Finalized cutoffs are
64 or above, B-
43 or above, C-

Midterm difficulty is ok la, many of the skills used to solve examples demonstrated in class will appear in the midterm.

Final is more challenging.  Time is tighter.  Though, I tried MATH 2011's final exam this sem (time limit tight as fuck!!) and I think MATH 2023 final exam is easier...  Maybe MATH 2011 is afraid that students will cheat so they made time limit even more ridiculous than MATH 2023!  Zhang Hai's exams are definitely easier than Ivan Ip's.

Finally, in 107 students,
5 students attain A+
35 students attain A- or above
64 students attain B- or above
79 students attain C- or above

Scores for reference:
10% Assignments, 39.5/40
10% Webwork, 10/10
25% Midterm, 50/50
55% Finals, 94/100
Overall 96.575.

To study this course, strongly recommend:
- watch YouTube Professor Leonard Calculus 3 for basic understanding
- attempt all of the optional problem sets on canvas by Prof Frederick Fong, they are all high quality questions, very worth the practice.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderately heavy.

13 webworks
4 challenging but short assignments
1 midterm (1 hr)
1 final (2 hrs)

Time limit for exams:
2020 Midterm (2 hours)
2022 Midterm (1 hour)
2022 Final part 1 (30 mins)
2022 Final part 2 (50 mins)
2022 Final part 3 (40 mins)

reviews.comment_grading:
I bet it was decent the last year and the last last year and so on.
But holy fuk was it bad this time.
HHM deliberately cut the final exam time to 2 hours which was 3 years for years.
He however pumped the difficulty up resulting in a nightmarish exam.
I have a good understanding of the course material, manage to finish past paper early and get most of them right.
This exam however just didn't give you enough time for anything.
Not to mention, it was 2/3 MC which means a slight mistake in calculation lost you the entire question and the precious time.
It just doesn't worth it to invest time on any MCs if you haven't finish LQ which probably will take away all your time anyway.

If you consider yourself lucky, choose this course with HHM because you might get an A if you can guess the MCs right out of pure luck.
Otherwise avoid HHM at all cost.
He can't design an exam. He just can't.

reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly I won't blame his teaching given the overall teaching quality in HKUST is so shit. He can show clear examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
A guy's comment on it is very classic.
MATH 2121
Lecture: x^2 + 2x + 1 = 0
Homework: x^3 - x^2 + x + 3 = 0
Exam: x^3 + 2x^2 + x = 0

MATH 2023
Lecture: 1+2 = 3
Homework: 1+1 = 2
Exam: Using divergence theorem to find <x^2,y^2,tan-1(x^2+y^2 + z) over a cone. (Indeed in a exam question he asked it)

The exam has really huge "Divergence" comparing to homework and lectures. He cut the time to a strict level, meanwhile asking more and more questions involving a large amount of crazy calculations. I do the three long questions easily in the final, but the MCs are just like oh holy fucking shit. Sometimes you know how to do that, but facing the crazy parameters and variables, you are so tired, so confused, and it is easy to game over once you made a little silly careless mistake, everything's gone.

I am not a guy excellent in playing MC tricks. So I GG this time. And this course may probably be my lowest grade math course in HKUST.

reviews.author: Halis
reviews.title: 令人又愛又恨的 Jimmy Fung
reviews.comment_content:
10: 3D graphs, multi-variable functions (Lines and Planes)
11: Vector-valued functions of one variable
12: Partial differentiation
13: Application of partial differentiation
---------------------------------MIDTERM---------------------------------
14: Multiple integrations
15: Vector fields
16: Vector calculus
------------------------------------FINAL------------------------------------

內容等同美國嘅 Calclus III。

content-wise 非常豐富。每一課都係全新嘅內容，而且係build up on 上一課嘅野，所以你邊度唔係好明嘅話好即刻去maths support centre 清 concept，如果唔係你會追得好辛苦。但啲內容係極度有用，可以應用係business、engineering等不同範疇。
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy Fung 教嘢好有邏輯，著重解釋 concept (rice bowl <- 上佢堂就明)，proof 嘅嘢都會教但會盡量簡短，上堂基本上唔會悶。好有心教，試過開 extra lecture 連續教三個鐘追進度。有時佢會整 notes上堂派（course website 未必有），仲會教你考試要點樣答先係有效率地攞分，超好人。佢成日想同學生互動，但大家似乎唔多show佢 :( anyway 佢係一個好 professor，reg佢實無錯，reg唔到就 sit 堂啦。

(p.s. 但佢 2019 fall 嘅 final 安排得好垃圾，詳情睇其他comment)
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme 1: 10% webwork; 30% midterm; 60% final
Scheme 2: 10% webwork; 45% midterm; 45% final
小弟 midterm 43 (below 1 sd); final 70.3 (above 1.5 sd); grade: B+

正常 grading 啦，同其他數學 course 差唔多。

(p.s. 都係個句，2019 fall final 好垃圾，完全唔知點計分)
reviews.comment_workload:
只有 webwork，同1012 1014 一樣。

但認真講句，Workload 幾多視乎你目標。如果你 aim D range / C range，每份 webwork 上網抄答案，臨 final 溫一兩日其實就得。

但如果你 aim B range / A range，Jimmy Fung course website 上面會有好多練習題目，係由出版社嘅書入面精挑細選出黎嘅例題。有心嘅假設你做六至七成，再加埋 tutor 俾落嘅練習，計埋計埋 workload 就頗大。

reviews.comment_teaching: I think Ivan is a new professor as this is the first semester for him to teach 2023. His teaching style is similar to TK Lam as his lecture notes are hand-written. His teaching is quite good but definitely too fast for me, I cannot follow. He will upload the notes and in class exercise solutions on canvas, so students can review it later.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is OK, 25% in total will guarantee a pass, but still over 10 students are given a F due to the difficulty of the course.

Midterm is super difficult, mean is around 43/100. Final is a little bit better than midterm, mean is around 48/100. Hitting mean 2 times is a B-.

I personally think that the grading in Spring semester are worse than fall. From what I observed in the class, most of the students are year 1 mainland and IRE students with very strong mathematical background, they are all very smart. Students who take 2023 in year 1 Spring are all elites.

(Reminder for ECOF students, if you are thinking whether to take this course for whatever reasons, better don’t take this course, and don’t listen to what prof LSF said. According to prof LSF, students cannot get good grade in 3113 without 2174/2023. However, 3113 only uses the knowledge of lagrange and partial D, but in 2023 you need to learn TONS of new maths... I would choose to learn 3113 one hundred times, but not 2023 for once.)
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork every week.

reviews.author: TheSkillfulNoob
reviews.title: Best math professor I've met here
reviews.comment_content:
- Just read others comments' if you wish to know what is EXACTLY discussed in the course - here are just some personal interpretations.

- Pretty essential if you intend to further pursue a major in math. Really advise taking Math 2011/2023 right after you finishing 1014.

- Advantage over 2011 (which is commonly thought to be easier) is that, you could learn about the calculations and theorems in greater detail: Divergence theorem and Stokes' Theorem are not taught in 2011 - they provide you with convenient methods to transform flux integrals into forms that are much easier to evaluate.

- In my opinion, if you really wish to build a good math foundation, MATH 2023 is definitely one of the best starters (after MATH 1013-14) you would wish to take early in your uni life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although sometimes with local accents and explanations only in Chinese, Jimmy did engage me greatly with body languages, jokes (e.g. about food when discussing forms of 3D surfaces, or "go in one ear and out the other" (左耳入右耳出) in discussing flux) and his enthusiasm.

He would also responsively explain the concepts to you once again if you don't understand them at first - just be proactive and reach him out!

Or if you don't prefer always attending classes early in the morning/ or watching the zoom recordings (like me, sorry Jimmy...), go tutorial exercises! Theorem statements/ examples and exercise solutions are provided and I think they are intelligible enough to students within 1-2 hours of digesting each.

Compared to the (boring, I am sorry) classes I've attended in MATH 1013/14 last year, this math course is definitely much more engaging and meaningful! Kudos to Jimmy :P
reviews.comment_grading:
Exams were said to be really challenging in the past, particularly in the case for prof. Ip (who usually teaches in spring). However, Jimmy was quite easy-going examwise in the finals and featured relatively simple questions compared to past years' finals.

Homework (15%) mean: ~85/100 (Me: 99)
Midterm (25%) mean: ~50/100 (Me: 84)
Exam (60%) mean: ~47/100 (Me: 87.5)
Final grade: ~54/100 (Me: ~88)
Grade: A+

I believe Jimmy's grade handouts have been quite lenient already: From the midterm and final graphs, I should be at around the top ~5%, which typically should only make me deserve an A only from my experiences of other courses here in UST. Grateful for the 'leng' grade and his excellent teachings!
reviews.comment_workload:
Homeworks could be of slight pain, particularly when you are finding the theorems a bit hard to digest well within a limited time. There were 10 (almost weekly) compulsory homeworks on Webwork with 10 questions each; questions featured were of standard type but only 3 attempts were given, so you might need to be quite careful. I spent ~1.5 hours for each piece of the homework for the last few pieces as they could be a bit hard to solve when you're still not yet familiarised with the items taught.

TA provides notes and exercises for each of the topics taught; though those pieces of exercises are optional, I STRONGLY advise anyone taking MATH 2023 to go over them and summarize the strategies required to solve the questions - to get what the theorems or proofs mean.
Spoilers (sorry): there were on average 30-50 questions on each (of the 12) tutorial notes and they usually take a few hours to complete - to get yourself reasonably equipped and perform well in your assessments, some hard work is definitely expected...

There are also optional "exercises for students" made by Jimmy himself, with more challenging questions featured. If you want to get a good grade, at least try going over the suggested (underlined by him) ones as they really do provoke your thoughts rather than being merely "train-up" materials.

After all, this is a 4-credit course so you should expect some workload...

reviews.author: id@a
reviews.comment_content:
In general, interesting and useful knowledge.
And I think in most case, you are taking this course if and only if you are a math major student, so, you have no choice but to take it regardless of whether you like it :)

Equation of straight line, scalar/vector projection, distance between point/line/plane and distance between point/line/plane
Visualizing curves, arc length
Function of two variables, limits and continuity, partial derivative, chain rules, gradients of functions and directional derivatives
Extreme values and Lagrange multiplier
Multiple integrals, Jacobian
Vector field, Div and Curl, line integral, conservative vector field, surface integral, flux
Divergence theorem, Stoke's theorem (and Green's theorem)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Best professor for me. He explains the math concepts in a very specific(like using a rice bowl to explain the concept of level set) and clear way and does many examples in class to let us familiar with the algorithms. He is also a humorous person that he often rises funny examples.
Also, everything is clearly explained in his notes (but I still strongly recommend you to attend his lectures).
Sometimes he tells jokes in Cantonese in classes. If you are a local and understand it, it make you have a better lecture. If you don't understand it, it's still fine.
But sometimes the schedule of teaching in lecture is not match with that of the tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
N/A
The final example has not yet started.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light

A webwork assignment per week, no webwork in the midterm exam week. Should be able to finish in several hours. If you do not get stuck to any questions, should be able to finish in one hour. Usually three attempts for each question.

A set of *optional* homework. Suggested to do them though they are not graded.

A set of "Exercise for student", refer to Jimmy, its "for students who want to get A+ only, because finishing the optional homework is enough to get an A alr. No answer will be given by me and the TA because it is Exercise for student instead of Exercise for TAs or Exercise for professors"    So I pass them lol.

reviews.author: uaena
reviews.title: Interesting and useful course, awesome lecturer.
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Vectors and the geometry of space
Chapter 2: Vector-valued functions
Chapter 3: Partial derivatives
Chapter 4: Applications of partial derivatives
-- Mid-term Exam --
Chapter 5: Multiple integrals
Chapter 6: Vector calculus
-- Final Exam --
Chapter 7: Differential forms

This course is a continuation of MATH1013 and MATH1014. Before mid-term, the content will be mainly about vectors, parametrization, partial derivatives and finding extrema. After mid-term, the focus would be on integrals and characterization of conservative vector fields. The final exam is cumulative, but chapters 5 and 6 take up a significantly greater proportion in the final exam paper. Chapter 7 is not covered in the exams and is for leisure reading only. Henry held a lecture after the end of the semester but before exams to go through this chapter, to satisfy our curiosity.
(I think our class is targeted at non-MATH-major people, so I guess Henry put more emphasis on application than proofs in his teaching as compared to the other class. The two classes have different test papers too.)
reviews.comment_teaching: May as well give an S here if I can since Henry is probably one of the best teachers I have ever met. His lecture notes are interactive and well-organized, I find it quite helpful to understand things by completing the lecture notes during lectures with his guidances. He also gives us lecture notes of MATH1013 and MATH1014, which I'm really grateful for since the MATH1014 lectures I have had didn't cover vectors due to time constrain. I am always astonished to receive his emails every Saturday, in which he summarizes the week's lecture, talks about upcoming topics and reminds us of upcoming deadlines. He uses a lot of examples and similes (and sometimes memes too) when he explains things that are really comprehensible and fun.  He is very patient and enthusiastic to solve our queries (you may ask in Cantonese if you prefer to). It is always thrilling to ask him questions since I can often learn a lot of things and have a clearer understanding afterwards. He also replies to emails very quickly. He could have better time management to reduce the need for overrunning lessons and having an extra lesson on a public holiday (understandable though). It has been an awesome learning experience overall.  Thank you, Henry :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
60% Final Exam
30% Mid-term Exam
10% WeBWorK
+3.5% Bonus for Extra Problem Sets (2-3 selected questions per set, hand-written full solution, optional submission)

Statistics (from what Henry posted)
Mid-term:
Full = 60, Mean = 29.98, SD = 13.2, Max = 60, Upper quartile = 41,  Median = 30, Lower quartile = 19.5
Final:
Full = 100, Mean = 45.3, SD = 21.1, Max = 85.5, Upper quartile = 63.5, Median = 46, Lower quartile = 28

I got around mean for mid-term, slightly above mean for final, almost full marks for assignments and got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: 10 compulsory WeBWorK assignments and 7 optional extra problem sets for the whole semester. Attendance for lectures and tutorials is not taken. It would definitely be insufficient to sit for the exams without extra practice and revision in addition to completing homework, if you want a good grade. (Personally think completing the problem sets, including those that are not assigned as bonus homework, is  useful to test and enhance our understanding, as well as for exam practice.)

reviews.comment_teaching: Zhang Hai is a professor willing to answer students' emails and questions. He is a pretty nice guy. However, I don't think he teaches well, his English ability restrains his teaching performance. I skipped most of his lectures. Zhang Hai would upload every lecture notes and pre-lecture notes and it's worthy of studying. MATH2023 is not a proof-based course and not studying some rigorous math, but he tried to teach it more rigorous, which I think is quite good.
reviews.comment_grading:
assignment 10%
webwork 10%
midterm 30%
final 50%
I got 94/100 on midterm and 90/100 on final, and full marks in HWs. I got an A+
Midterm statistics: mean 56 sd 25
final exam statistics: mean 49 sd is around 27
As you can see, athough the mean is low, the grading distribution is M-shaped. If you want to have an A range, shall get perform well in both midterm and final. With one exam performed unsatisfying, you will easily get a B.

Before exams I did the problem sets on canvas for practicing, which I think is a good way for preparing.

reviews.author: Arkux
reviews.title: Need to spend effort
reviews.comment_content:
Vectors, space curves and its parametrizations, level sets, partial differentiation and its applications.

Multiple integration and its applications, change of variables(to Cartesian/Cylindrical/Spherical coordinates, Jacobians), vector fields, line/surface integrals, del operator(Grad/Div/Curl), Divergence/Green's/Stoke's Theorems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy's lectures can bring a lot of fun. He can demonstrate space curves using network cables from LT, or 3-D surfaces using a rice bowl. He is willing to return a 3-hour make-up lecture once a normal lesson(1.5 hours) is cancelled in whatever reason.

Jimmy also mixed some philosophies during lectures. In his classes, you are not only learning math, but also the importance of "maintaining a good personal relationship" or something like that. Very experienced, responsible, comical and memorable professor in UST.

But he speaks English with a strong Hong Kong accent, and some Cantonese if he doesn't know how to translate(like 毛筆，武林秘籍etc). Some gags might require an understanding of Cantonese.

If you are familiarized with his accent, you will enjoy his lectures.

By the way, TA's notes and explanations are also quite detailed and 貼地. But I am too lazy to give more comment here.

Overall, praise both Lecturer and TA for their teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Webwork
30%(15%) Midterm
60%(75%) Final

The performance in the midterm was quite poor since the mean is only about 30/100, which will absolutely lead to a bad grade if this trend continues. On this account, Professor tried to "pull" up the scores using different manners(in this semester) such as:

-introducing a new grading scheme(weights of Webwork/Midterm/Final→10/15/75%), and
-giving a bonus quiz, and the scores of which(up to 10 pts) will be directly added to the midterm score,

so to encourage us not to give up too early.

Fortunately many questions in the final exam were quite similar to those in Homework! I spent around 2 days going through all the homeworks before the final and therefore found the exam questions much easier to tackle.

My score:
Webwork 99.05/100
Midterm 51+3/100
Final 86.5/100
Grade    A

Thanks to the new grading scheme.
reviews.comment_workload:
Basic requirement: One Webwork assignment per week. (10%)

↑While trying to do as many exercises as you can in order to understand the entire content.

The resources may come from:
- Professor's Homework (No need to hand in, but some questions inside might appear in the exams. Put this as the FIRST PRIORITY)
- TA's notes
- "Exercise for Students" on the Lecture Notes

↑Usually enough.

To summarize, Webwork is light but far from sufficient. Need to put extra effort.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: Great course, great instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Calculus III
Ch1: Vectors and the geometry of space
Basic vector stuffs, most of them should be covered in MATH1014. Together with some 3D geometry.

Ch2: Vector-valued functions
Parametrisation of curve. Actually I don't know what is going on here when I study this topic.

Ch3: Partial derivatives
Derivatives in 2 or more variables, computation wise is similar to those in single variable calculus. However, there is a big difference in concepts like Differentiability, Continuity, Existence...I still don't know what they are after finishing this course...

Ch4: Application of partial derivatives
Gradient for local max/min/saddle points, Lagrange's Multiplier for max/min in boundary. Finding the absolute max/min. (This should be very useful in many other subjects.)
-----midterm-----
Ch5: Multiple integrals
Double Integral, Triple Integral, Iterated Integral, Integration techniques (spherical coordinate, cylindrical coordinate), curves, surfaces, Change of Variable (Jacobian Determinant)

This chapter is very important as it will be the tool to solve all questions in Ch6.

Ch6: Vector calculus
Vector fields, Curls, Divergence, Conservative Vector Fields, Line Integrals, Surface Integrals, Green's Theorem, Divergence Theorem, Stoke's Theorem

Exciting Chapter, FINALLY I KNOW WHAT I AM DOING FOR THE PAST 5 CHAPTERS. If you have studied PHYS1112 before, then all the ideas of Ch6 will prove so many things that your professor skipped (like path independence, work done along a curve, moment of inertia (Maybe you know this in Ch5)). Since there is so many theorems and different kinds of cases you have to considered (in R^2, R^3, orientations of the curves/surfaces, parametrisation of the region...), this will be the hardest chapter...but still very exciting in learning them. (Maybe it is more applicable and can be visualised easily)

Ch7: Differential forms (For curiosity only, not in final)

Your basics in Math1013 and 1014 will determines how good you are in early chapters. Something you thought is a baby in single variable calculus will become a monster in mulcal :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Henry is excellent. He is nice and willing to answer questions in class (even the question is so stupid). Explanations of ideas are perfect.

One thing that is great of him is that he will send out a weekly reminder, roughly stating all materials we learnt this week and the deadlines of webwork and extra assignments. There is too many content in this course. It will be good to look at these reminders and revise those you have forgotten.

He is lenient in grading extra problem sets. Those problem sets are designed for him to check how do we answer long questions in each topic. He will still gives you full mark even if you cannot finish all the questions required/make so many mistakes. One time I was being a deadline fighter and skipped some questions/just list the approach of how will I solve this problem. Still got full marks...Thank you Henry ;)

I will say his notes are very well-organised and easy to understand. He sends out his own Math1013 and 1014 notes for  revision, much better than those "lecture notes" in current Math1013 and 1014 sessions. Henry should also be teaching these courses...I really think his notes and his teaching will save many freshman ;(
ALSO HE HAS GREAT ENGLISH :D Thats already worths an A.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am writing this early because grades may affect my mood and you may not find such a detailed review :)
Will update after releasing grades.
10 webworks (10%)
7 extra problem sets (extra 3.5%)
midterm (30%)
final (60%)
reviews.comment_workload:
No attendance but it will be good to attend his class. Basically webwork every week and problem sets every two weeks.
Final is basically not cumulative, there are only few questions solely examine materials before Ch5.

Workload really depends on what grades you are aiming.
If you aim an A, even if you got A range in both 1013 and 1014, the course content is not that easy. You still have to put a lot of effort to understand what is happening :)
The amount of course content will overwhelm you and Henry is rushing the content since Lecture 1, we still had lecture on the typhoon day :)

The extra problem sets will be a good practice before midterm and final. There are too many things have to be stated clearly before computation(like domain of parametrisation, orientation of surfaces/curves), be aware of that.

Maybe Calculus III in Khan academy helps because it is taught by the 3B1B guy. Though I love him so much, I don't have time to watch his videos :(

reviews.author: wen moon ser
reviews.comment_content:
The course name is a bit misleading. This course should be named Multivariate and Vector Calculus.

The course is very all-round. You are able to deal with multivariable calculus and vector calculus after this course. You will be able to interpret the mathematical notation in this field after taking this course. However, some contents were deleted due to unsatisfactory performance in the midterm.

Course Content:
1. Vectors, dot product, cross product, vector-valued function, distances between points, lines and planes
2. Graphs and functions in 3D graph - plane and quadric surface, level sets, cylindrical coordinate, spherical coordinate
3. Parametrization of function, space curve, derivative of space curve, arc length of space curve
4. Multivariable functions, continuity, partial derivative, gradient, tangent plane, chain rule, differentiability, directional derivative
----------------------------Midterm------------------------------------
5. Critical points of multivariable functions, D-test, Lagrange multiplier
6. Double integral, double integral in polar coordinate, triple integral, triple integral in cylindrical and spherical coordinate, jacobian
7. Vector fields, divergence and curl of vector fields
8. Line integral, potential function, surface integral
9. Divergence Theorem, Green's Theorem, Stoke's Theorem
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy Fung is a very funny professor. He uses extra materials to explain his words. For example, He brought his own bowl to show us the geometric interpretation of a quadric surface and related problems. He also made some models for us to be able to view the intersection between two surfaces.

On the other hand, he is able to explain the concept clearly with very tidy handwriting and extraordinary drawing which are super helpful during revision and thinking. He speaks English with some Hong Kong accent but not so difficult for understanding. However, sometimes he will speak Cantonese for some words in order to express his idea precisely.

He provides incomplete notes so don't skip lectures otherwise you actually don't understand the contents.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 grading systems:
Grading system 1:
Webwork 10%
Midterm 30%
Final 65%

Due to super poor performance in the midterm, there is an extra way for grading. Plus, Jimmy added a bonus of maximum 10 marks to midterm through bonus quiz.

Grading System 2:
Webwork 10%
Midterm 15%
Final 75%

Performance in Midterm
Mean: 29/100
Standard Deviation: 18/100
Performance in Final
Mean: 52/100
Standard Deviation: 25.7/100

For me:
Midterm: 49/100
Bonus Quiz: 7/10
Webwork: 100/100
Final: 89.5/100
Final Grade: A

I think the grading is quite good. If you hit mean in both exams, you can get B- according to my friends.

P.S. The midterm is extremely hard. It tested on something that had not been taught in the lecture (i.e. curl of a vector field)
Plus, it required you to think out of the box to solve some questions. Comparing with it, Final was way easier and most question you could find in Jimmy Fung's notes and assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork every week and each webwork around 10 questions. Some questions have limited attempts so have to be very careful when dealing with them.

On top of webwork, Jimmy posts some extra assignment selected from the textbooks, which are super useful for preparing for the final and midterms as some questions will turn up again.

reviews.author: I love ust <3<3
reviews.title: The BEST Instructor I've Ever Met
reviews.comment_content:
Before MT:
-------------
First 2 weeks
Vectors, Dot products, Projections, Cross products and etc
Followed by 3D coordinate geometry: planes, surfaces, no much calculus is included except the tangent vector.
-
Then partial differentiation:
Partial derivative, Chain rule, Gradient operator, Lagrange Multiplier
----------------------
MT: Everything taught before Lagrange Multiplier will be examined
----------------------
After midterm:
-------------
Double integral, Triple integral, Change of coordinate system for integration, Jacobian Transformation, surface area.
***Vector Calculus***
Vector Field, line integral, surface integral, divergence, curl, flux, Divergence Theorem, Green's Theorem, Stoke's Theorem.
-
*Vector Calculus would be quite hard for students without any physics background like me as Jimmy will use physical interpretation to explain vector calculus, students without physics background should better search for geometric interpretation online to understand more about it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy teaches very well, he can explain everything with daily examples, a clear picture will appear in your mind. He can literally visualize everything, by drawing, using a rice bowl, cables etc Just follow his way to solve problems would be able to excel the final exam.
-
Try NOT to skip his lecture, he is very funny, tried hard to make students appreciate maths, like when he was teaching Gauss (Divergence) Theorem and Green's theorem, he would first tell you some history about Gauss and Green, as well as their contribution towards maths. He not only teaches us knowledge in the notes but also inspires us :D
-
And Jimmy puts a lot of emphases on drawing and indeed it is the most important part in multivariable calculus. If you can sketch the surfaces, planes, you know how the volume looks like, then everything else would be straight forward enough. Do practice your curve sketching skills, the drawings you will be encountered in this course should be easy and standard enough.
----------------------
The TA Hugo also tried hard to teach us, yet I found his problems in his handout is far from the course, maybe those questions are easy and standard in his point of view(he is a HKUST alumni, also taught by Jimmy, those problems might be the questions he had in those years) And somehow he always talks about irrelevant stuffs in the tutorial class, always says that "your will learn it in "Chapter XX", which will be covered in next month" or "This is XXX in complex analysis", kind of wasting time for these irrelevant stuffs.
But he is really nice , passionate and kind, always sends us reminder emails before exams, even after the course he sent us an email about how to get prepared for MATH 2033, he's really a nice guy, I just dont like about his question and those irrelevant stuffs.

reviews.author: Ver
reviews.title: Thoroughly enjoyed this course!
reviews.comment_content:
This course is a direct follow-up to content from MATH1014 Calculus II. After reviewing concepts on vectors and equations in three dimensions, the course introduces multivariable functions. Key concepts include:
- Arc-length Parametrization
- Partial Derivatives & Chain Rule
- Directional Derivatives & Gradients
- Tangent Planes, Critical Points
- Lagrange's Multipliers
- Double & Triple Integrals
- (Conservative) Vector Fields & Line Integrals
- Surface Parametrization & Surface Flux
- Green's, Stokes' & Divergence Theorems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Fong has prepared a beautiful summary document of lecture content, organized like a short textbook. His lecture slides are written in class, and extremely organized and easy to follow. Every class follows the same format: review, lecturing main concepts, and examples. This format made content easy to learn and understand.
Prof. Fong is also very approachable and willing to help. He gives very good guidance when we do not know how to approach a practice problem.
reviews.comment_grading:
There were two grading options:
1) 5% WebWork, 40% midterm, 55% final
2) 100% final
Whichever grading method gave a better mark was used.
Two bonus problems were given this semester. For the first problem, the first two correct students were awarded one point and half a point respectively. For the second problem, bonus points were awarded to the first two students who would improve by a sub-grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The only graded homework is weekly WebWork assignments. Problem sets are also given weekly and covered in tutorials, but they are optional. Extra WebWork questions are also provided for students who would like extra review.

reviews.author: Andrew Onymous
reviews.title: Difficult Course, but with Great Content
reviews.comment_content:
Covers differentiation and integration in multiple variables (at most 3), vector fields and their respective applications.
A strong foundation in basic calculus is highly recommended, as they will be necessary throughout the course, but they won't be taught (such as differentiation by parts, etc.). I suggest revising the basics again before taking this course.
Mostly working within 3D space.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor explains everything clearly, and his diagrams are neat. He is also patient in answering our questions. The professor also uploads interactive 3D graphs which help us to better grasp the complex concepts in 3D space.
reviews.comment_grading:
Even though I've put in a lot of effort into this course (I focused on this course the most), I still received an unsatisfactory grade, and that is mostly due to the fierce competition.
I did all of the exercises and then some, but apparently the others were better.
The exams are all written questions.
There is also a bonus quiz, which is a chance for you to obtain extra marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for this course is very heavy or light, depending on what grade you aim to achieve.
There's only a total of 10 weekly homework that is compulsory. However, if you want to achieve good grades, you have to put in way more effort.
There are tutorial examples, and the professor also provides practice questions which are quite a lot, but they are still not enough. You should do extra exercises from the textbook if you want to get good grades.
You really need a solid understanding of all the concepts, and at the same time you have to memorize the multiple Theorems.

reviews.author: whateverla
reviews.title: an above average couse
reviews.comment_content: 2023 is multivariate calculus. Although it is taught by ivan, it may sacrifice a little rigor in some places for the sake of progress or considering the acceptance of students. It lacks a little detailed explanation of the applicable conditions of certain conclusions, but it will be supplemented appropriately A counter example is used to explain the failure situation. If you want to fully understand it, you may have to do a small lesson in private. However, because this course is relatively less rigorous, the exam and homework focus more on calculations, which will not affect The proof has very high requirements (Ivan's original words are: we don't want to grade 80 proofs), but once I calculate it, I can easily make mistakes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ivan himself feels very friendly. This sem formed a WeChat class group, so I was able to add his WeChat. I often ask him questions in private chats on WeChat, and he often responds quickly and in detail. There is no airs at all. I often send all kinds of WeChat soy emoticons hahahaha (really very very very very cute hahahahaha). Once I skipped class at noon to go to LG7 to eat dan dan noodles. After eating, I found that Ivan was sitting behind me eating alone. Because I was guilty of skipping class, I didn’t dare to say hello to him, but I noticed his hair at a close distance. It looks far less than in zoom just a little bit :)
reviews.comment_grading:
In terms of the content of the exam, mt will prove a little bit. After all, the knowledge in the first half of this class is not too much to use for calculation questions. In the final, because I have learned a few theorem, I am basically calculating surface integrals and curve integrals, so it is calculated Be careful not to misread the title when reading (it's me). But after all, it is ivan's class, the mean is very low, mt is 39.9/100, and final is 30.2/100, so of course this class is not just an absolute turtle. The specific rules for the turtle are:

Obtaining a total point of 95% or above, or top 5%, will guarantee an A+.

Obtaining a total point of 75% or above will guarantee an A-range.

Obtaining a total point of 30% or above will guarantee a passing grade.

Looking at the letter grade, in a hall of about 80 people, there are 10 people with F, almost half of them are B and above, and the mean is just about between B and B-. The proportion of A range is about 18/80, and there are 5 people with A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Because the time of this class is stuck at noon, I either feel sleepy or go to eat, so I basically haven’t attended class after mt (don’t remember attendance). My impression of this class is basically stuck in notes, but it seems to listen to classmates It is said that the attendance rate of this class is also pitifully low. Maybe the reason why everyone does not go is similar to mine? Even less than half of the people went to the final review session to take class photo in the last section.

reviews.author: Evanescence
reviews.title: Not quite well-structured course
reviews.comment_content:
Week/Key Topics
1 Three-Dimensional space (section 12.1), Quadric Surfaces (section 12.6) , Vectors in the plane (section 12.2) , Vectors in three dimensions (section 12.2) ,Dot products (section 12.3)
2 Cross products (section 12.4), Lines and planes in 3-space (section 12.5)
3 Calculus I of vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Calculus II of vector-valued functions, Length of curves (section 13.1, 13.2, 13.3)
4 Functions of several variables, level curves, limits and continuity of functions of several variables, partial differentiation (section 14.1, 14.2, 14.3)
5 Differentiability of functions of several variables, Chain rules, directional derivatives and gradient vectors (section 14.5, 14.6)
6 Gradient vectors, Tangent planes and linear approximations, Maximum and Minimum values (section 14.4, 14.7)
7 Extreme values, Lagrange multipliers (section 14.7, 14.8)
8 Double integration on rectangular regions, double integration on general regions, polar coordinate system (section 15.1, 15.2, 15.3)
9 Double integrals in polar coordinate, surface area, triple integrals in rectangular
coordinate system (section 15.4, 15.6, 15.7)
10 Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system (section 15.8), line integrals, vector fields and line integrals in vector fields (section 16.1, 16.2)
11 Flux of a vector field, path independence, potential functions and conservative vector fields and Green’s theorem in the plane (section 16.3, 16.4, 16.5, 16.6)
12 Surface integrals, flux of a vector field across a surface (section 16.7)
13 Divergence theorem and Stoke’s theorem (section 16.8, 16.9)

It’s ok for the first-part topics, however, for the last topics which are most covered in the final, it’s quite miserable and confusing. The logic line is distorted.

10% by Webwork

Literally who decided to put math courses as absolute grading. It is absolute insanity. The mean is always around 30% and the still put passing grade as 40% so safe to say a lot of people get C range. Absolutely crazy and unnecessary.

Grade Thresholds (Guaranteed score to get the grade)
A+ 95% or above
A Range 85% or above
B Range 65% or above

Passing Grade 40% or above

reviews.author: udontknowmyname
reviews.title: Jimmy, nice guy indeed.
reviews.comment_content:
There are many other reviews that have listed the course content so I'm not gonna talk about it here.
In general I think they are not so hard and actually I think it's quite easy to understand the course content. (Easier than MATH2121 for me, anyway).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is not good. I'm just trying to find a word that can do better than "good". "Good" is so lame to describe Jimmy's teaching.
He delivers everything clearly. You can easily understand what he is talking about. He has a little accent but that shouldn't be a problem. I think he also tries his best to make his lecture more lively. He would tell jokes or say something funny to us from time to time. I can never forget how he taught the existence of limit. He really danced around that night lol. Anyway, boredom is the one thing you can't get from his lecture. Apart from teaching I think he really cares about students a lot. On the last lecture he talked about how we should be more proactive and speak up. It's kind of an old-school speech but still, I feel great because my professor actually cares about us and is willing to talk about something that is not on the syllabus to try to make us better. I think he's the best professor I've met in UST so far.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite good.
I think I didn't do well in my midterm because of some stupid mistakes and thought I could only get a B range. But my final saved me. But still, I got better grade than I expected.

Some statistics:
Mean:
HW(15%): (Not shown in system and I'm not gonna compute either)

Total: 49.32
Me:
HW(15%): 99.23%

reviews.comment_workload:
Depends.
The only compulsory homework is webwork, around 1 each week. If you only do this the workload is quite light.
I think paying attention in class, reviewing after each lecture and finishing the webwork can guarantee you an A range already. But still, I think it's quite beneficial to do the homework set which is not required to hand in and exercise for students. They are definitely good practices, give you a more solid understanding, and surely build up some of your confidence (in preparedness, mostly). If you choose to do all these, then the workload is somewhat huge. But this is a 4-credit course, so I think it's fair.

reviews.author: melon123
reviews.title: Henry is nice!!!
reviews.comment_content:
-Massive Content
-Good foundation in MATH1013/23,14/24 is a must (Henry even provided MATH1013 & 14 Preparation notes before the semester started)
-Builds upon basic algebra and calculus, and extend to 2d, 3d dimensions
-An interesting thing is that some of the intuitions you used in 1d algebra and calculus can be applied again to 2d and 3d cases with some notable differences
-Includes things such as Lagrange multiplier, partial derivatives, chain rules, curl, and divergence...
reviews.comment_teaching: Henry is a super nice professor. I asked tones of questions, but he still replied in a short period, with detailed enough explanations. His lectures are lengthy and always overrun, but it is reasonable because of the course content volume (or else the entire content can't be finished)
reviews.comment_grading:
Final is VERY IMPORTANT

Even you get just a bit above mean in the midterm, if you work harder and improve in the final exam (say get >1 sd), it is possible you can get A-range.

Don't miss the problem sets as they can provide bonus marks to your final score.

Believe in yourself. Not just IMO medalists/IRE students can get A/A+. This course is more about understanding the concepts thoroughly more than being creative in tricks/techniques, so pay HARD work and nothing is impossible.

reviews.comment_teaching: Clear and slow at computational problems. May take a lot of time solving basic computations. Can explain proofs but should spend more time on them.

reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.comment_content:
This course covered Chapters 10 to 16 of the textbook Calculus: A Complete Course by Robert A. Adams & Christopher Essex (9th edition). Course content includes:

1. Basic Vector Algebra (Dot and cross product, vector equation of lines and planes)
2. Parametric curve (curvature, torsion and Frenet frame is NOT included)
3. Partial differentiation (Definitions, chain rule, gradients and directional derivatives)
4. Applications of partial differentiation (Second derivative test and Lagrange multiplier)
5. Multiple integration (Double and triple integrals, Jacobian)
6. Vector Calculus (Line and surface integrals, Divergence theorem, Stokes' Theorem and Green's Theorem)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy Fung explains concepts clearly. He does a lot of worked examples after introducing a concept. He often brings a rice bowl to lectures to make it easier for us to have a pictorial intuition of some 3D concepts. He also welcomes questions before and after lectures and answers your questions patiently.

Jimmy Fung's lectures are also full of joy. He often make jokes (some of which are in Cantonese, so it may not be as funny for international students) during lectures that keeps our attention.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading system was 10% Webwork + 30% Mid-term + 60% Final Exam OR 10% Webwork + 45% Mid-term + 45% Final Exam.

However, owing to political events occurred in mid Nov, the final exam was conducted on Webwork instead. The Webwork final exam was slightly easier but the time was extremely tight (in that nobody on Earth can complete it on time). However, I believe that Jimmy adjusted the marks and so our scores are still at a reasonable level.

Statistics:
Webwork mean: 93.12
Mid-term mean: 57.86
Final exam mean: 54.26
Overall mean: 60.34
reviews.comment_workload:
For each week, you get a new webwork, which is going to be due two weeks afterwards. The questions are rather easy and are more like helping you to grasp the concepts taught in lectures.

There was a mid-term exam on late Oct and a final exam on mid Dec. The major workload for this course, in my opinion, was the preparation for the exams. It requires a large amount of drilling and practicing before you are fast enough to finish the exams on time, which matters a lot if you aim high for the course. So, do expect a rather heavy workload for those who aim at A range for the course.

reviews.author: Leif
reviews.title: Fair grading and great teacher
reviews.comment_content:
The content covers an appropriate breath and depth of both differential and integral calculus with multiple variables.

The first and second week are simply just reviews on the vectors, line equation and plane equations. This is simply a review of material learnt in high school.

The third week to the sixth week, covers mainly the differential calculus portion, which includes partial derivatives, directional derivatives, tangent planes, multivariable functions and Lagrange multipliers.

From then on, was the integral calculus and vector calculus portion. This includes material such as field vectors, line integrals, Green's theorem, Stokes' theorem (not discovered by Stokes') and Divergence theorem.

Overall, the content covered is not overwhelming and would benefit those who would want to pursue a career in engineering, physics or mathematics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ivan Ip is a very good lecturer as not only does he have the enthusiam to teach but he is also quite entertaining, allowing the students to engage in the lessons. In addition to this, professor Ip is willing to teach material outside the scope of the class. I was suprised that he was willing to teach the generalized Stokes' theorem and some suffix notation which is required in tensor calculus. Like myself, those who would want to pursue a career in pure mathematics or theoretical physics, this will most likely spark your interest.
reviews.comment_grading:
The weighting are as follows:
Homework: 5%
Midterm: 35%
Finals: 60%
Bonus: 3%

Homework is the typical webwork which is relatively easy to do.

The midterm was far more difficult than the final as the maximum was 86.5. This is not because of the content but instead the time contraint, as the midterm was the same length of the final but an had 2 hours as opposed to 3 hours.

The final exam was much easier, as there was 3 hours and the content covered in the exam was very similar to that of the lectures and the finals review.

Overall, I think the grading is rather fair, the only reason why I gave this a B instead of an A is because the A and A+ cut was very tight as only 4 people out of 110+ students got an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy at all.

fair grading

reviews.author: nacerchadli22
reviews.title: Webwork is easy, HOMEWORK is the key. "Exercise for students is for students only, so don't ask me."(Jimmy,2018-19Fall)
reviews.comment_content:
Sequences, series, gradients, chain rule. Extrema, Lagrange multipliers, line integrals, multiple integrals. Green's theorem, Stroke's theorem, divergence theorem, change of variables.

  For me materials before midterm is more abstract and requires me more time to understand. Make sure you are familiar with curve parametrization, chain rule and continuity problems before midterm.

Materials after midterm will be less abstract but more computational. I suggest you to revise on integration techniques from math 1014 or at least try to integrate stuff before taking the course. In the lecture Jimmy will tell you don't bother to integrate things in order to prepare for final exam but it turns out that computational mistakes of integration costed me more than 10% of marks in the final exam so do at least try to integrate stuff my friend.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy is a really great lecturer. He has great sense of humour, decent presentation skills and also passion for teaching. For example, he will bring a rice bowl to the class and even made a model of a 3D region and show it in class in order to make us understand the concepts more clearly.

  Although Some may criticize that he put too much emphasize on some minor things such as underlining vectors and stating that F(x,y,z)=0 is a level set in 3D before finding the normal to a surface. However for students who are not really mathematically talented students like me his advice makes me more clear on what I am doing when I am working on problems.
Also for students who will be taking this course I suggest you to attend Hugo's tutorial besides of lecture. Hugo explains concpets clearly and the example questions provided by him are of high quality.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork 10%
Midterm 30%/15%
Final 60%/75%
Best Scheme

Originally the scheme with 75% on final does not exist, but since generally people did bad in the midterm and in order to prevent student to give up on this course Jimmy provided the second grading scheme and also bonus quiz for students who get unsatisfactory marks in their midterm to boost their midterm score.

I did really bad in the midterm and get only about 2x out of 100. Compared to midterm, final much easier but I made a couple of careless mistakes so I only managed to get 6x/100.Eventually I only got B.
reviews.comment_workload:
THIS COURSE CERTAINLY HAS LARGE WORKLOAD

Although Jimmy always say webwork is easy but it actually costs you a lot of time to finish it as a lot of computational work is required. But the thing is Jimmy will not be testing you on computational things so you should as well complete the HOMEWORK (NOT exercise for student at the end of lecture notes) in order to familiarize yourself on what Jimmy will really test you about. I personally did not worked on any problems in HOMEWORK before midterm and I screwed up the midterm and I do regret about it a lot.

reviews.author: MATH學渣
reviews.comment_content: The content is appropriate, not too difficult nor too easy. The course focuses on the reasons and proofs behind each theorem or statement.
reviews.comment_teaching:

His notes are easy to understand. He also tells us which part is important in the notes.
reviews.comment_grading: The exam is a bit difficult. My midterm is ~0.5 SD above the mean (mean: 30.x/90) and I got 6x/100 for my final (mean:4x/100 as I remember) (he didn't release the stat of the final). And I got B for my grade.

reviews.comment_content: The content is a little bit difficult but very interesting. And it's a basic course that is useful for many other subjects. You need to listen to class carefully or you may not get A range.

reviews.comment_grading: If you study hard and have some talent, it may be easy for you to get A range.
reviews.comment_workload: There is a weekly homework on Webwork. Also there are some student exercise and other homework prepared by Jimmy. A certain amount of exercise is necessary to get high scores and grades.

reviews.author: sick ranchez
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content:
Great content. Covers most if not all of the core concepts in multivariable calculus. The course also explores interesting applications in other fields, most especially physics.

Lecture notes are quite helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Zhang uploads the lecture material after every lecture. Most of the examples he uses are from the lecture notes (which he uploads at the start of the semester), so if you've read the notes ahead of time, it should be easy to follow. It's a bit boring at times but in general it's fine. He's also really open to questions, so feel free to ask. No attendance.

The TA Hoi was excellent. He tried to engage the class, would give us tips, and would really try his best to help us understand. He's also makes jokes and is pretty lively.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Homework
30% Midterms
50% Finals

Grading is not bad. Almost everybody gets 100% for HW because you have unlimited attempts for each question. For my class the mean was around 70 for midterms and 60 for finals.
reviews.comment_workload:
For homework, it's just webwork (one per week), so it's quite light. However, I recommend reading the lecture notes before the lectures so that the lectures will be easier to understand.

There is one problem set for each lesson, though this will not be submitted. Some of the questions are quite interesting and answering these problems really helps you understand the lesson better.

reviews.author: Andreas

reviews.comment_content: Expands on the ideas covered in single variable calculus to multi-variables, including vector calculus, partial and full differentials of multivariable functions, critical points of multivariable functions. Other topics covered in this course involve integration in multi-variables and vector fields.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching in lectures if very straight forward and clear. Lecture notes are well structured and synchronised to the lectures teaching method and order.
reviews.comment_grading: Due to the non-subjective nature of solutions in mathematics, correct answers are given full credit, and incomplete answers are given credit where they are merited. Expect full marks for a complete answer and some marks for incomplete answers showing some degree of understanding.
reviews.comment_workload: One webwork per week. Self discipline is crucial to ensure that one has enough practice in this course.

reviews.author: ChuaWanZhen
reviews.title: A very useful course for Physics students
reviews.comment_content: Professor Jimmy Fung has reduced some topics as he found out that there is insufficient time to cover all of them. In this course, you can't just memorize all the equations only, it is better to know the derivation. He might test you on it and there are not much of numerical calculations. It is important to keep practicing on the derivations.
reviews.comment_teaching: I really like his teaching. He always welcome questions from students and encourage interactions, although most of the time we just sit back on our seats quietly. He not only teach us Mathematics but also attitude. He encouraged us to be passionate, hardworking and persistent.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good. Professor Jimmy always offers us a second chance. So, even though you didn't do well during the midterms, you still stand a chance in your finals. The weightage for the final is much higher (around 3 times the midterm). That is why he always encourages us not to give up.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for the webwork is very light. Professor Jimmy gave us a lot of optional exercises, which are not required to be handed in. However, I can say that it is essential to FINISH all of them to master the content. Furthermore, exercises are very important when it comes to Mathematics. He would test on the questions that are somewhat similar to the exercises that he gave us. So, be sure to finish all of them. The Webwork questions are relatively easy compared to the extra homework and exam questions.

reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Ku 教得不錯，但他打不切notes, 到study break的時候才補足所有notes。 因此，若想跟上進度就要上課抄notes
reviews.comment_grading: 古語有云:「認住jimmy fung，爛grade好輕鬆。」因此，我選了Albert Ku的堂。但是，試卷是一樣的，而我不知道garde是否分開派。只要你高mean兩個sd或以上，A range輕鬆達到。目測mean為C/C+左右，以MATH字數來說還可以吧
reviews.comment_workload: 只有webwork，非常輕鬆。當然，professor會提供一些「額外」的exercise給你自習用。而這些exercise有99%都會出現在考試中。因此，若果懶得溫書，看看這些exercise，背solution manuel就可以了

reviews.author: David Hwang
reviews.title: MATH2023
reviews.comment_content: Mainly deals with vectors, lagrange multiples, multiple integrals, regions in 3D(Type 1,2 and 3), line integral, conservative fields and three big theorems, Green, Stoke and Divergence,
reviews.comment_teaching: his teaching is very clear. accents and pronunciations are fairly pleasant hearing. lectures are well paced, rarely runs out of time. Prof. Ku is very willing to answer  questions during the lecture or after class in his office room.very nice person,
reviews.comment_grading: you have to put a lot of efforts in order to get A range. studying the course materials are good enough, but a solid understanding in every concepts are demanded for A range. SD of exams can be well illustrated in a simple word "crazy." SD of 30~40 can be expected. due to this big SD, it is very hard to fail the course but, D~C+ is fairly expectable for those who just learn the surface of the materials.
reviews.comment_workload:
homework are only those webworks uploaded every week, there is 1% extra credit quiz with does not affect your overall even though you receive a zero in that.

study load can be said as very heavy because you need a lot of practice on those concepts learned. Procrastination of studying will lead you to D at the end.

for those Bio and Chem students, this course is not your required course, therefore don;t even think about enrolling into this lecture just because you are interested in Math. It will destroy your major GPA and TGA.

reviews.author: kptss88
reviews.title: essential but still bad grading as usual
reviews.comment_content:
This is a math major required course and essential for any courses using math that is more than one variable.
呢個course 主要將 MATH 1013,1014 1D calculus 推廣到 2D,3D, 所以若果你有 2D,3D 嘅sense (即係類似DSE 做3D trigo 諗下D角,邊咁, 不過呢次係面同立體) 已經嬴人成條街.

1. 3D space: vector equations of lines and surfaces in 3D space,
                     quadric surfaces, coordinate systems
2. Vector functions: **parametrization of curve, calculus of vector
                                functions, arc length
3. Partial differentiation: **limit and continuity, partial derivatives,
                                      **chain rules, total differentials, gradients
4. Extreme values, **Lagrange multiplier
5. **Multiple integration: double and triple integrals,
                                      change of order, Jacobian, surface area
6. **Vector field: line integrals, surface integrals
7. **Vector Calculus: Divergence theorem, Green's theorem,
                               Stroke's theorem
(** means very important topics you have to pay attention)

好多人搞唔點係因為唔知/唔記得呢個course已經係講緊2D,3D野, 唔係仲係1D, 所以一定有2D,3D sense. 雖然Jimmy Fung堂上面已經成日係咁提都咁爛grade, 但無計, 唔係人人都有嘛...
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jimmy Fung 我覺得算係MATH dept. 入面幾好嘅prof., English好已經萬幸, 上堂間中講下爛gag都唔錯. lecture note會唔齊, 佢會堂上講清楚點解題, 有時仲自製notes, 佢教multi. cal.都好耐, 知道同學會錯咩位, 會係個到著重講深入d; 可惜係, 呢個sem 2023係 9點堂, 個人未訓醒, 好多時會聽漏左...
但佢對學生都幾嚴, 試過一兩次係堂上話要認真上堂, 搞點好MATH; 試過中途停低罵我地要專心唔好訓 (9點堂,想點啫...), 咁嘅professor, 好唔好見仁見智啦
有樣真係唔係幾好嘅係, 係LTC耐唔耐就會一次個喇叭會超高頻炸一炸個耳仔, 黎緊仲係LTC嘅話要小心

Zeta Chan 做TA 真係唔錯, tutorial儘量都揀佢, 雖然最重要係week 2 佢1st tutorial 派個份exercise (網上有answer, but only answer), 佢上堂會抽幾條explain點做, 有時做幫手清下concept, 問佢問題都會好願意答你, 不過有時佢有d chinglish 都幾好笑
reviews.comment_grading:
10% webwork
30% MT
60% Final
聽翻人講mean都係得 C range, 真係爛到一個點..., 但MATH course d grade 算係咁啦

MT 只係出1-3 (4唔太記得有無), very easy, 明到lecture講咩, 做下tutorial exercise都輕鬆考. mean~60, sd~25, 算高
但ust出名樣野: midterm 易, final 難, 份final難到完全唔夠時間做, 出哂 ch. 1-7, 最重要係change of order, vector field and 3 theorems(真．大佬, 好多人都死係佢手上), mean~47, sd~25

(真心mode) 各位有志入MATH major嘅同學, 請三思; 已入左/真心想入嘅, 就唯有加油啦, 之後嘅點都會用到multivariable calculus教嘅野, 同埋, 之後嘅會更爛... (但聽講好似好過engine嘅MATH 2011..)
reviews.comment_workload:
同1014一樣, 都係得MT, Final, webwork, workload 唔算大, 係個webwork 比1014 會難左d.
Jimmy佢另外會每個chapter出一份homework, 但唔駛交, 唔計分, 想普普通通嘅話做唔做無所謂, 但aim at A range 嘅就一定要做.

Also, Zeta 俾個份exercise最好做哂, 幫到手清concept.

reviews.author: adqqqqqqqqm
reviews.title: why even
reviews.comment_content:
The course content before midterm is simple and you should be able to handle just by reading the notes by yourself without attending lectures. I only started attending lectures after midterm when he was teaching vector calculus, but I don’t think it was worth the time either.

The course included everything normally except divergence theorem because the professor ran out of time or just didn’t want to teach it (?) Either way it doesn’t really matter just read it by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I don’t think his teaching is bad. It was clear and the pace is okay. Nothing much to complain about.
I didn’t attend a single tutorial so can’t say anything about them.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is COMP1021 mode, the exams are very easy and so one careless mistake could cost you. The exams test how careful you are and the scores measure how well you slept the previous day. So don’t expect to get an A+ here as you will need essentially full marks.

Grading
10% HW (webwork, infinite attempts)
35% Midterm
55% Final

Midterm
High: 101
UQ: 95
Mean: 70.34
My score: 92

Final
High: 100
UQ: 86.75
Mean: 62.2
My score: 96

Grade: A

The only difficult parts of the final were the true or false questions at the start, which are apparently, shamelessly copied along with a few long questions from past papers of this course. Prof. Ho Quoc, you deserve a thumbs down for that.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload does not deserve 4 credits at all. The assignments are all webwork, which you can finish quite quickly. Not a lot of preparation is needed for the exams either, just do more exercises for practice. If this course is worth 4 credits of workload then MATH1023/MATH1024 should be 10 credits.

reviews.author: JaydenShek
reviews.title: Ho Hon Ming is the best!!!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Week1: Three-Dimensional space, Quadric Surfaces, Vectors in the plane, Vectors in three dimensions,Dot products
Week2: Cross products, Lines and planes in 3-space
Week3: Calculus I of vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Calculus II of vector-valued functions, Length of curves
Week4: Functions of several variables, level curves, limits and continuity of functions of several variables, partial differentiation
Week5: Differentiability of functions of several variables, Chain rules, directional derivatives and gradient vectors
Week6: Gradient vectors, Tangent planes and linear approximations, Maximum and Minimum values
Week7: Extreme values, Lagrange multipliers
Week8: Double integration on rectangular regions, double integration on general regions, polar coordinate system
Week9: Double integrals in polar coordinate, surface area, triple integrals in rectangular coordinate system
Week10: Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system, line integrals, vector fields and line integrals in vector fields
Week11: Flux of a vector field, path independence, potential functions and conservative vector fields and Green’s theorem in the plane
Week12: Surface integrals, flux of a vector field across a surface
Week13: Divergence theorem
reviews.comment_teaching: Ho Hon Ming is really a good leccturer. All the concepts and steps on finding inttegrals and 3-D space thinking are nicely taught. Well explanation in overall. However, the examples shown in class are extrememly simple. Don't refer to them when you revise the MT or final. It is different levels. Some how just like the difference between hell and heaven.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Henry is a very very good teacher in multivariable calculus. For each concept, he would provide an computational example to help students understand the theorem. Besides, Henry always give an inuitive and the proof for each theorem and technique,like change of  iterated integral order in triple integral ( which I feel quite challenging in the first couple days) and 3 vector field's theorem.
  Besides the performance in lecture, he provides the lecture notes/material from MATH 1013/1014/1020 for some topics are highly related to the course. Students can have a quick review from them and understand the material in 2023 better.
  Last but not least, Henry is a patient instructor, he answer the question from the chat box patiently. You may find him during his office hour or send an email for f2f appointment if you wish (you may ask in Cantonese if you prefer to). His explanation is clear and precise(explain +give example under 1.5hours for ch.7).  You probably can learn a lot from him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
60% Final Exam
30% Mid-term Exam
10% WeBWorK
+3.5% Bonus for Extra Problem Sets (2-3 selected questions per set, hand-written full solution, optional submission)

Statistics (from what Henry posted)
Mid-term:
Full = 60, Mean = 29.98, SD = 13.2, Max = 60, Upper quartile = 41,  Median = 30, Lower quartile = 19.5
Final:
Full = 100, Mean = 45.3, SD = 21.1, Max = 85.5, Upper quartile = 63.5, Median = 46, Lower quartile = 28

The grade is pretty good,I got 71.67% in MTT, 72% in Final, 3.5 in bonus and 94. 47% in web work. Got A.
reviews.comment_workload: There are10 Webwork and 7 optional bonus extra problem sets (3-4 question need to hand in) .Attendance for lectures and tutorials is not taken. It would be great to complete all the questions in extra problem set because there is lots of different type of questions inside the problem set like derive and calculate moment of inertia, 6 change iterated integral order in triple integral etc. Master those technique would definitely help you do the exam and mid term faster and get a good grade.

reviews.author: 數學研究生
reviews.title: Easy course but rubbish grade
reviews.comment_content:
Multi variable Calculus of course teaching you how to do with 2 or 3 variables in the same time. (But as a Math student, I really don't understand why there is no any Honor courses for people who like to think about multi-variables, like n variables or do things in general)

That means it only covers 2 to 3 variables (x, y and z). Students who have studied M2 in their secondary schools may have some advantages since the content will cover vectors, dot product and cross product in first few lectures. People who are good at space thinking are encouraged to study this course, since it will be a good grade course for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecturer is very funny, a Hong Kong lecturer who can make you laugh at his lecture. But the pronunciation of English is really make me feel annoying. Try not to miss any class, he is really a funny guy.

The TA is also a Hong Kong resident, but sometimes may make me feel unhappy especially when I asked him questions. He tried to define every thing very rigorously, e.g. you need to be careful on "derivative" and "differentiation". If you asked him using a wrong word, he will be angry on you and you will feel unhappy. Since that time, I never attend his tutorial lessons any more.
reviews.comment_grading:
Rubbish Grade as I said.

Jimmy said if you can get an overall 80% of the marks, you could get an A range grade. Do not trust this statement 100%, since if you can get 80 marks you can only get B+ or more than that will be A-, no A for you. If you really want an A, try to get 90 or above, mainland students are waiting for your challenges.

Some of my mainland friends can easy get 85 or above since they did most of the exercises, as a lazy guy, I did not do any exercises and did not study but attended all the lessons finally can get in B range.

Be careful about the midterm and the final exam, try to check your paper and see Jimmy's solutions, once I found that he is not good at setting questions and providing solutions. He used the angle of a marker to give out the solutions which is the thing that I hate for. Once, I asked him how do you know you need to use this method, what is the hints from the question. And he always tells you you need luck sometimes. As a paper maker, I always write my solutions as a candidate does but not at the angle of a marker.
reviews.comment_workload: Difficult to say, a lot of exercise that you can practice. There is an online assignment every weeks. Easy to get 100% correct.

reviews.author: mark_
reviews.title: Useful course and interesting content, and OK professor.
reviews.comment_content:
Useful for many physics and engineering applications while also interesting for pure maths enthusiasts.

If you are doing a MATH major, planning on double majoring maths, or are just interested in pure maths, take MATH2023.

If you are only taking this for the physics and engineering applications though, take MATH2011 instead.

Content:

(Copied from Syllabus)

Vectors, lines, planes, curves in three dimensional space
Functions of several variables, continuity, partial derivatives
Chain rule, directional derivative, gradient
Tangent plane, total differential
Maxima/minima, Lagrange multiplier
Double integrals, rectangular and polar coordinates  
Triple integrals, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, change of
variable  
Vector fields, line integrals, conservation of vector fields
Curl operator, Green’s theorem
Parametric surfaces, surface integrals
Surface flux, Divergence theorem
Stokes theorem
reviews.comment_teaching:
Hai Zhang teaches well and seems to care about your understanding, even in online mode. He often teaches some of the intuitive ideas and proofs behind the concepts we use, even if it's not strictly required. The lectures are usually fairly interesting, which is no accident as I see he prepares the content very well.

In online teaching, he is good at keeping up with the chat and responds to questions quickly. He is also very approachable by email (more so than the TA I got).

However, his accent is quite hard to understand at times. He also goes too fast sometimes, and I have to review the lecture notes immediately after class to understand something.

I did read that others found him too quiet at times, but it's not a problem in online teaching it seems.

The tutorials are a good place to review concepts taught a week ago and ask questions on anything unclear. I found they usually are about a week behind the lectures in terms of content, which is good as you will have somewhat digested the content before reviewing it.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% WebWork
10% Assignments
25% Midterm
55% Final

OVERALL
---
This semester's grade boundaries, with the cumulative grade number of students given (there are 107 total students enrolled):
95% -> A+ (5 students)
85% -> A range (35 students)
64% -> B range (64 students)
43% -> C range (79 students)

This means the A-range is 32.7%.

One has a chance of receiving a higher grade than the boundaries specify based on individual performance, completion of homework, and attitude.

Unfortunately, according to the professor, quite a few students failed the course this semester.

ASSIGNMENTS
---
The assignments can be hard, but you have lots of time to finish them.
Mean: 33.9/40

MIDTERM
---
The midterm is not too hard compared to the practice problems and assignments. It should be doable if you do your practice.
Mean: 37.47/50

FINAL
---
The final exam, on the other hand, is a bit harder. This semester specifically, some of the questions were quite difficult. According to the TAs in the group chat, people did not do that well in this final. So, the grade boundaries this semester may be lowered.
Mean: 60.31/100

I made a lot of careless mistakes in the midterm and even misread an entire part so I got 42/50. I also just made lots of computational errors in the final and got 82/100. I also got one mark deducted in an assignment and got 39/40 for them overall.

Overall, I got 85.85% which led to an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderately heavy. 1-2 Webworks every week and the occasional written assignment.

The assignments are quite time-consuming, so it may take a few days to finish. Certainly do not leave it to the last minute, as you will not finish.

He also made a typo in one assignment which caused me to spend a whole week on a problem when really it should have only taken 30 minutes...

Understanding the concepts also takes quite a lot of time, so reserve some time (especially once you get to vector fields) to revise the content if you want to do well.
